node.title: How to compile and run my source code？
node.bodyText: I just started learning to use moose, and my source code: .c documents and .h and .i file, how to calculate on my moose and get the result？Do I need to write the makefile by myself?

Follow the instructions here to create an application: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/new_users.html
After the application is made, you can place your source in src and include and the pre-generated makefile will compile appropriately.

Thank you for your answer. I tried this, After compiling, I tried to run input.i file in my registered application, but this error occurred. Do you know how to overcome this problem.
the following errors were reported：
A 'Migration' is not a registered object.
If you are trying to find this object in a dynamically linked library, make sure that
the library can be found either in your "Problem/library_path" parameter or in the
MOOSE_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable.
Code.zip
thank you so much！！!

node.title: Data output of grain growth model
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE Experts,
I've started studying the example poly_grain_growth_2D_eldrforce.i.
But I don’t know how to output the evolution of the number of grain boundaries of each grain over time, or the distribution of the number of grain boundaries at each time step.
Any suggestions or recommendations to fix these problems would be greatly appreciated.
Thanks
wei peng
@SudiptaBiswas Can you help with this?

I'm not sure I understand why you mean by "number of grain boundaries of each grain". Are you wanting the number of grains each grain is adjacent to? If we are on a grain boundary are you interested in the number of grains each boundary is adjacent to? We have a few existing AuxKernels that can visualize this information. There is also the FeataureVolumeVectorPostprocessor that can output several "per grain" quantities. If we don't have exactly what you need available now, it shouldn't be difficult to get that information.
Yes, I want to output the number of neighboring grains for each grain during the time evolution. So what AuxKernel or Postprocessor can achieve this function?

Currently this information is not stored. It is saved in the initial condition system (to build the graph coloring matrix), but it's only used in that one instance. However, it is indirectly available during the discovery phase each time the FeatureFloodCount object executes, so it could potentially be saved. I don't have time or scope to work on this for you, but I would be willing to advise you on how to modify the source to accomplish this. You could contribute your changes back to MOOSE too. Are you interested in working on this?
Yeah, I am very honored to contribute to MOOSE. My job is to couple tensor mechanics and phase field to study the process of grain growth, so the grain boundary output is very important to me.

BTW - Shameless plug: I have a new publication that should have a preprint available shortly that goes into a lot of the detail of how these algorithms all tie together. Maybe by mid to late December. I'll try to remember to post the link here when I have it available.
Thank you for your enthusiastic help, and I am very sorry to reply to you now. I will read your suggestions carefully, and hope to achieve what I need. Thank you again for your guidance.

hi permcody, @permcody
I want to clarify the information I need to output again in the phase field grain growth simulation.
In the simulation of grain growth, the information that needs to be captured is two major aspects.


The first is grain-growth kinetics, which is mainly the grain size distribution at each time point.
The second is topology of grain-growth-induced microstructures, which needs to be able to output a series of csv files similar to the first one, and each csv file represents the topology of grains at different time nodes.

The content of the topology includes:

the number of faces (sides) per grain, in other words, the number of adjacent grains of a certain grain. I think this is the purpose of writing this object.
the number of edges per grain.
the number of vertices (corners) per grain.

According to your suggestion,you are going to have to look through the FeatureFloodCount object a bit and understand what's there. I just tried to read the code to understand FeatureFloodCount, but I found this is difficult for beginners like me. So, could you share some basic documents with me, such as the program framework of FeatureFloodCount.C, the entry-level information of this algorithm, etc., so that I can better understand the FeatureFloodCount object.
Finally, I am very sorry to reply you after such a long time. I hope that I could complete the editing of this object with your help and make some contributions to moose, which will also give me a deeper understanding of moose.
Thanks
wei peng

Hi @permcody, I think I'm done with outputting the number of adjacent grains by adding some code in FeatureFloodCount and FeatureFloodCount. And I also have made a pull request. Looking forward to your comments.
Wei

node.title: Persistent response following steady state restart
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am a new MOOSE user trying to simulate some basic elastic deformation. At the moment, I have a solid with a given density initially responding to the gravity loading, with some pressure boundary at its front. I have a first input file detecting the gravity equilibrium with a given tolerance. Then I use the resulting exodus file for the initial mesh and conditions in my second input file where I want to apply different time-dependent forcings.
The steady state detection runs as expected, however once I run the second input file with the exodus file in steady state (with the same boundary conditions), I still get a relatively high initial response before a new steady state is reached. While I would have expected a smooth start without very minor variations in displacement as the system should already be in steady state.
Below are the input files for gravity equilibrium and transient evolution. In an attempt to narrow down my problem, the input file for transient evolution doesn't include any additional forcings.
Two notes:

Trials at the default steady state tolerance did not solve the problem.
Transient evolution is properly starting with the mesh and system of the steady state at the last time step.

I built those two input files based on MOOSE examples (especially MASTODON) but I probably missed some conditions/objects or set some parameters with values that are preventing my system from staying in steady state at the restart... I tried to find the solution by myself, but I am now stuck without explanation.
Any help would be much appreciated! Thank you a lot in advance!
gravity_equilibrium.i
# input file initially based on MASTODON Soil_Response.i ex09

# ------------------------ 

# slope of the bottom boundary (in degrees)
bed_slope = 15 

# change coordinate system to add a slope
gravity_x = ${fparse
  	      cos((90 - bed_slope) / 180 * pi) * 9.81
              } 
gravity_z = ${fparse
	      cos(bed_slope / 180 * pi) * 9.81
              } 

# account for slope in BC on displacement  
# bed_factor_x = ${fparse
#              	 cos(bed_slope / 180 * pi)
#                 }
# bed_factor_z = ${fparse
# 	         sin(bed_slope / 180 * pi)
#                 }

# ------------------------

[Mesh]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z' 

  [channel]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = channel.e
  []
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  mass_damping_coefficient = 0.2
  stiffness_damping_coefficient = 0.2
[]

[Variables]
  [disp_x]
  []
  [disp_y]
  []
  [disp_z]
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [vel_x]
  []
  [accel_x]
  []
  [vel_y]
  []
  [accel_y]
  []
  [vel_z]
  []
  [accel_z]
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [gravity_x]
    type = Gravity
    variable = disp_x
    value= ${gravity_x}
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []
  [gravity_y]
    type = Gravity
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0.
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []
  [gravity_z]
    type = Gravity
    variable = disp_z
    value = -${gravity_z}
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []
  [DynamicTensorMechanics]
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
    static_initialization = true
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []
  [inertia_x]
    type = InertialForce
    variable = disp_x
    velocity = vel_x

    beta = 0.25

  []
  [inertia_y]

  []
  [inertia_z]

  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [accel_x]
    type = NewmarkAccelAux
    variable = accel_x

    velocity = vel_x
    beta = 0.25
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
  [vel_x]
    type = NewmarkVelAux
    variable = vel_x
    acceleration = accel_x
    gamma = 0.5
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
  [accel_y]
    type = NewmarkAccelAux
    variable = accel_y
    displacement = disp_y
    velocity = vel_y
    beta = 0.25
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
  [vel_y]
    type = NewmarkVelAux
    variable = vel_y
    acceleration = accel_y
    gamma = 0.5
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
  [accel_z]
    type = NewmarkAccelAux
    variable = accel_z
    displacement = disp_z
    velocity = vel_z
    beta = 0.25
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
  [vel_z]
    type = NewmarkVelAux
    variable = vel_z
    acceleration = accel_z
    gamma = 0.5
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
[]

[BCs]

  [front_pressure]
    type = Pressure
    boundary = 'downstream'
    variable = disp_x
    factor = 2
  []
  
  [anchor_bottom_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'bottom'
    value = 0.0
  []  
  [anchor_botom_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'bottom'
    value = 0.0
  []
  [anchor_bottom_z]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = 'bottom'
    value = 0.0
  []

  [anchor_sides_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'left right'
    value = 0.0
  []
  [anchor_sides_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'left right'
    value = 0.
  []
  [anchor_sides_z]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = 'left right'
    value = 0.0
  []
     
[]
  
[Materials]
  [elastic_material]
    # has been designed to simplify multilayer materials
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensorSoil
    layer_variable = '1'
    layer_ids = '1'
    poissons_ratio = '0.31'
    density = '0.9'
    shear_modulus = '3.8e6'
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
  []
  [strain]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [andy]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  petsc_options = '-snes_ksp_ew'
  petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_gmres_restart -pc_type -pc_hypre_type -pc_hypre_boomeramg_max_iter'
  petsc_options_value = '201                hypre    boomeramg      4'
  start_time = 0.0
  end_time = 10000.0 # 4.0
  dt = 0.01 # 0.001
  dtmin = 0.0001
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-4
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-5
  l_tol = 1e-5
  l_max_its = 25
  timestep_tolerance = 1e-8

  steady_state_detection = true
  steady_state_tolerance = 1e-5 # 1e-8 default
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  perf_graph = true
  print_linear_residuals = true
[]

# slope of the bottom boundary (in degrees)

Hello
Could you please try checkpoint restart and see if you get an initial steady start from the transient?
See https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_usage/restart_recover.html
Restart from exodus is much harder to achieve, because you run the risk of having forgotten an auxiliary variable (seems fine here), of solving the equations with a different scaling factor (not here) etc.
And checkpoints are much easier to use overall.
Guillaume

  exodus = true
  perf_graph = true
  print_linear_residuals = true
[]


transient_state.i
# input file initially based on MASTODON Soil_Response.i ex09

# ------------------------ 

# slope of the bottom boundary (in degrees)
bed_slope = 15 

# change coordinate system to add a slope
gravity_x = ${fparse
  	      cos((90 - bed_slope) / 180 * pi) * 9.81
              } 
gravity_z = ${fparse
	      cos(bed_slope / 180 * pi) * 9.81
              } 

# account for slope in BC on displacement  
# bed_factor_x = ${fparse
#              	 cos(bed_slope / 180 * pi)
#                 }
# bed_factor_z = ${fparse
# 	         sin(bed_slope / 180 * pi)
#                 }

# ------------------------

[Mesh]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z' 
  file = gravity_equilibrium_out.e
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  mass_damping_coefficient = 0.2
  stiffness_damping_coefficient = 0.2
[]


[Variables]
  [disp_x]
    initial_from_file_var =  disp_x
  []
  [disp_y]
      initial_from_file_var =  disp_y
  []
  [disp_z]
      initial_from_file_var =  disp_z
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [vel_x]
    initial_from_file_var =  vel_x
  []
  [accel_x]
    initial_from_file_var =  accel_x
  []
  [vel_y]
    initial_from_file_var =  vel_y
  []
  [accel_y]
    initial_from_file_var =  accel_y
  []
  [vel_z]
    initial_from_file_var =  vel_z
  []
  [accel_z]
    initial_from_file_var =  accel_z
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [gravity_x]
    type = Gravity
    variable = disp_x
    value= ${gravity_x}
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []
  [gravity_y]
    type = Gravity
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0.
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []
  [gravity_z]
    type = Gravity
    variable = disp_z
    value = -${gravity_z}
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []
  [DynamicTensorMechanics]
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
    static_initialization = true
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []
  [inertia_x]
    type = InertialForce
    variable = disp_x
    velocity = vel_x
    acceleration = accel_x
    beta = 0.25
    gamma = 0.5
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []
  [inertia_y]
    type = InertialForce
    variable = disp_y
    velocity = vel_y
    acceleration = accel_y
    beta = 0.25
    gamma = 0.5
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []
  [inertia_z]
    type = InertialForce
    variable = disp_z
    velocity = vel_z
    acceleration = accel_z
    beta = 0.25
    gamma = 0.5
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [accel_x]
    type = NewmarkAccelAux
    variable = accel_x
    displacement = disp_x
    velocity = vel_x
    beta = 0.25
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
  [vel_x]
    type = NewmarkVelAux
    variable = vel_x
    acceleration = accel_x
    gamma = 0.5
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
  [accel_y]
    type = NewmarkAccelAux
    variable = accel_y
    displacement = disp_y
    velocity = vel_y
    beta = 0.25
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
  [vel_y]
    type = NewmarkVelAux
    variable = vel_y
    acceleration = accel_y
    gamma = 0.5
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
  [accel_z]
    type = NewmarkAccelAux
    variable = accel_z
    displacement = disp_z
    velocity = vel_z
    beta = 0.25
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
  [vel_z]
    type = NewmarkVelAux
    variable = vel_z
    acceleration = accel_z
    gamma = 0.5
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
[]

[BCs]

  [front_pressure]
    type = Pressure
    boundary = 'downstream'
    variable = disp_x
    factor = 2
  []
  
  [anchor_bottom_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'bottom'
    value = 0.0
  []  
  [anchor_botom_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'bottom'
    value = 0.0
  []
  [anchor_bottom_z]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = 'bottom'
    value = 0.0
  []

  [anchor_sides_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'left right'
    value = 0.0
  []
  [anchor_sides_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'left right'
    value = 0.
  []
  [anchor_sides_z]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = 'left right'
    value = 0.0
  []
     
[]

[Materials]
  [elastic_material]
    # has been designed to simplify multilayer materials
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensorSoil
    layer_variable = '1'
    layer_ids = '1'
    poissons_ratio = '0.31'
    density = '0.9'
    shear_modulus = '3.8e6'
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
  []
  [strain]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [andy]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  petsc_options = '-snes_ksp_ew'
  petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_gmres_restart -pc_type -pc_hypre_type -pc_hypre_boomeramg_max_iter'
  petsc_options_value = '201                hypre    boomeramg      4'
  start_time = 0.0
  end_time = 10000.0 # 4.0
  dt = 0.01 # 0.001
  dtmin = 0.0001
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-4
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-5
  l_tol = 1e-5
  l_max_its = 25
  timestep_tolerance = 1e-8
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  perf_graph = true
  print_linear_residuals = true
[]
I just did some more tests with very tight tolerances and other execution parameters. It unfortunately did not solve the problem so far...

Hi Adrien
This doesnt seem normal. I would run your inputs files but I dont have your mesh and do not have this ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensorSoil material object either in the tensor mechanics module. I imagine you created it.
The only thing I noticed is that the NewmarkVelAux and NewmarkAccelAux do not use the displaced mesh. I'm not sufficiently familiar with the Newmark time integration method, could that be the issue?
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
I wanted to attach my mesh but GIthub doesn't support exodus files for attachments.. I will think of a way to share it with you! ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensorSoil is from MASTODON, see here.

The only thing I noticed is that the NewmarkVelAux and NewmarkAccelAux do not use the displaced mesh. I'm not sufficiently familiar with the Newmark time integration method, could that be the issue?

Oh thank you, I will check and let you know!
Thank you a lot!
So I just added my mesh in my fork of MOOSE, here. (channel.e)
Thanks I ll try it out tomorrow!

nl_abs_tol = 1e-4
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-5

the second one seems really coarse. I m getting timesteps accepted with a 100 residual for the steady case. Even if it does end up stabilizing and meeting the steady-state criterion, the transient should also converge each step if we want to see steadiness. I ll look at that in more details
I did some tests with nl_abs_tol = 1e-12 nd nl_rel_tol = 1e-7 and could  get rid of large residuals (and no more warning) but still a similar response on restart...

The only thing I noticed is that the NewmarkVelAux and NewmarkAccelAux do not use the displaced mesh. I'm not sufficiently familiar with the Newmark time integration method, could that be the issue?

Interesting, when I use the displaced mesh on NewmarkVelAux and NewmarkAccelAux, the system is simply blowing up...! So there is definitely something here.

Another interesting note: on restart it's responding but then reaching another steady state, different to the one reached in the steady state detection. As if there were different local minima reached during the solve....

Can you paste your convergence history (the output log)?
My opinion is that the steady state has not been reached at the end of the steady.i run. I'm trying to see if I can converge it now
EDIT: ok I see the jump now. Seems larger than what this hypothesis would allow

In the MASTODON examples ( 6 & 13 ), NewmarkVel and AccelAux arent used with use_displaced_mesh = true so I think this isnt likely to be the problem.
I ll tag @cbolisetti for awareness of what we're trying
Can either of you share the input file? We have had some problems with steady state analysis and I tried to fix some of the issues in the past. Let me see if I can help.

The input for steady and transients are in the first post above, and the mesh is in the first comment of this reply
I m running a more converged simulation rn (steady state at 1e-8), with automatic scaling which seems to help as well

@AdrienWehrle and @GiudGiud, I was using my iPad app earlier and I didn't notice the earlier part of the thread with the input files. I now see that you are trying to run a gravity analysis using restart. We don't usually use restart analysis for the gravity step. We use the controls block to switch off the inertia kernel and other time-derivative-dependent terms (damping, for instance) in the first 2 time steps. This makes sure that a static analysis is performed at these time steps and the inertia kernels are switched on when needed. I think this is a much simpler way to perform gravity analysis. We have an example that shows this: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/mastodon/examples/example14.html
There is a note that specifically talks about gravity. Please let me know if this method works for you. If not, I can try to help.
Woh, thank you a lot @cbolisetti! It works like a charm and is way more efficient than a steady state detection in that case! Thank you a lot also @GiudGiud for your precious help!
Excellent! Please let us know if you need anything else.

node.title: Store several specific output into *.e format
node.bodyText:
Hello!
I have a question about storing the result file (*.e).
After the simulation, I want to store all output value into csv.
But simultaneously I would like to store the result for several specific time step.
e.g, 10 time steps.
All output value for 10 time steps.
5 results for every 2 step.
Is this possible? If yes, how can I get this?
I always appreciate your help.
Sincerely,
Hokon Kim

Hello
Just create more than one CSV block in [Outputs].
[Outputs]
  [csv_all]
    type = CSV
  []
  [csv_others]
    type = CSV
# use start/end  _step (or _time) + interval to do what you want

  []
[]

Note that step 1-10 then every five steps might not be possible with just the parameters we have now. You ll have to either change those parameters (not too hard coding), create a custom EXECUTE_ON (also not too hard coding), OR just have 3 CSV blocks and merge two of them afterwards

node.title: Error with MOOSE installation on INL machine for BISON building.
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I am currently trying to build BISON on INL machine SAWTOOTH3.
I followed the procedure (with PETSc module version 3.11.4-GCC) given in: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/bison/getting_started/hpc_new_clone.html.
All steps ran successfully until I built BISON. All of the errors displayed are reported on the file attached.
The error may stem from MOOSE installation. This is why I followed option 3 in  the procedure:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/PRs/20068/site/getting_started/installation/inl_hpc_install_moose.html
This time too occurred an error, reported on the file attached.
Do you have any idea about this error coming from ?
Thank you in advance for your answer.
Vincent GAUTHIER.
building_bison.docx

Hi Vincent
If you really do want to use the conda install, and suffer the performance penalty, you will have to purge that environment as you seem to have a broken mamba cache. This usually stems from a user interrupt in previous mamba commands.
The preferred way would be for you to install your own petsc. The petsc module is really old. I updated this PR, this is now option 2 on that webpage you linked.
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
I tried to install my own petsc with option 2, but I ended up with the same error message when I built BISON. (in the file attached).
Building PETSc.docx
let's just set up a call and check what's wrong. If that works for you, can you please email me some of your availabilities this week?

node.title: How to assign value?
node.bodyText:
Hello，
I have a set of 1D data along the z axis and then need to interpolate to the 2D boundaries of a 3D grid, how can I achieve this?

hello
Is this to initialize a variable? I ll assume so.
Use a FunctionIC to initialize the variable
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/ics/FunctionIC.html
with a PiecewiseConstant function with axis = z
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/PiecewiseConstant.html
Guillaume

node.title: Inquiry about BC in CH model
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I have a question about the boundary condition. If I don't set the boundary condition in the input file, what is the boundary condition that will be applied by default?

Haiying
No flux
So, this is for left, right, top and down boundary?
For the concentration on the top and bottom boundary, what value should I set?

any boundary that does not have a boundary condition will effectively have a no-flux BC.
There's more than one CH model. Which one are you talking about?

node.title: error message when running the input file
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I got an error message when running my input file in supercomputing center. The following screenshot shows the error:

Why is this? My simulation stops and would not run.
Does anyone have any suggestions about this?
Thank you very much.
Best regards,
Haiying

Hello
Is this for MOOSE or a MOOSE derived app?
Please follow those instructions to get a backtrace for the error
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html
Guillaume

Is there more to the error message that may be explaining the issue? When MOOSE throws an error, typically the actual user-friendly error message is printed before the MPI Abort, like this:
A 'PeripheralRingMeshGenerator' is not a registered object.

If you are trying to find this object in a dynamically linked library, make sure that
the library can be found either in your "Problem/library_path" parameter or in the
MOOSE_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
MPI_ABORT was invoked on rank 0 in communicator MPI_COMM_WORLD
with errorcode 1.

NOTE: invoking MPI_ABORT causes Open MPI to kill all MPI processes.
You may or may not see output from other processes, depending on
exactly when Open MPI kills them.

Here, the actual error message is telling you that A 'PeripheralRingMeshGenerator' is not a registered object., which you may not notice if you just look at the very end of the error message that talks about MPI. Some new users I've helped have missed the actual error message like this.
Is there other info in your error message? If not, then @GiudGiud's suggestion of a backtrace is the best thing to do.
